ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got an in-depth analysis of the period of the French Revolution. I also learned about the practice of intellectual history.

knowledge: history of the French Revolution, its major political and philosophical debates, and the key players
skills: analyzing one event from different perspectives (war, property, liberty, etc.), how to really do intellectual history
insights: French Revolution is a major touchpoint for the political conversations we are still having today

I really appreciated the way the course was set up to keep us on track for the final research paper; the feedback at different stages was very helpful. I also learned a lot about the different questions that were circulating at the time of the French Revolution and the ways people addressed them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strength - Nakhimovsky is very thoughtful and incredibly knowledgeable. It was a pleasure to take a class with him. I thought the topics were great.
Weakness - the readings were simply too much at some points, and although it was interesting for background, we definitely could have had more focused and involved class conversations if everyone had really done them all.

strengths: awesome mix of primary and secondary sources, of close reading and the big picture, of diving into the details and thinking about legacy today; fantastic syllabus covering the major thinkers and debates of the French Revolution; final paper and conference are incredible ways to see how much we still have to learn about the F.R.
weaknesses: sometimes class discussion lacked continuity, political thought (e.g. Rousseau) was sometimes invoked confusedly

I liked the idea behind the course but the actual experience of it didn't really match my expectations. In many cases, the readings felt overwhelming and unnecessarily dense, which could just be a function of the scholarship on the different topics, but sometimes we'd read a 60-page reading and barely discuss it among the 2 other readings that week. The discussion was also difficult to engage with at times: there was little genuine dialogue between the students and the questions would often fall flat.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Nakhimovsky is a fantastic professor, and the topic is amazing. I would recommend to anyone who's interested in history, democracy, or political theory.

I would only recommend this course if you already have some background knowledge of the history of the French Revolution or are interested in the domain of intellectual history. I feel like everyone in the class could've benefitted from a stronger understanding of the actual history of the Revolution before delving into the intellectual conversations at the time.
